Issues.Title: fix(core): Errors during ApplicationRef.tick should be rethrown in teâ€¦
Issues.Body:
â€¦sts with ZoneJS

Errors during change detection from `ApplicationRef.tick` are only
reported to the `ErrorHandler`. By default, this only logs the error to
console. As a result, these errors can be missed/ignored and allow tests
to pass when they should not. This change ensures that the errors are
surfaced. Note that this is already the behavior when zoneless is
enabled.

BREAKING CHANGE: Errors that are thrown during `ApplicationRef.tick`
will now be rethrown when using `TestBed`. These errors should be
resolved by ensuring the test environment is set up correctly to
complete change detection successfully. There are two alternatives to
catch the errors:
* Instead of waiting for automatic change detection to happen, trigger
  it synchronously and expect the error. For example, a jasmine test
  could write `expect(() => TestBed.inject(ApplicationRef).tick()).toThrow()`
* `TestBed` will reject any outstanding `ComponentFixture.whenStable` promises. A jasmine test,
for example, could write `expectAsync(fixture.whenStable()).toBeRejected()`.

Issues.Title: Angular deprecates `getLocaleDayNames` without providing a compatible alternative in `Intl.DateTimeFormat`
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

localize

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

In Angular 18, the `getLocaleDayNames` function has been deprecated in favor of using the `Intl` API for internationalization. This change is intended to make the framework lighter by relying on built-in browser capabilities. However, I've encountered an issue where `Intl.DateTimeFormat` does not provide equivalent short day names as Angular's `getLocaleDayNames`.

### Using Angular:
```ts
import { getLocaleDayNames, FormStyle, TranslationWidth } from '@angular/common';

const angularDayNames = getLocaleDayNames('en-US', FormStyle.Standalone, TranslationWidth.Short);
console.log(angularDayNames); // ["Su", "Mo", "Tu", "We", "Th", "Fr", "Sa"]
```

### Using Intl:
```ts
const intlFormatter = new Intl.DateTimeFormat('en-US', { weekday: 'short' });
const intlDayNames = [];
for (let i = 0; i < 7; i+=1) {
  const date = new Date(Date.UTC(2021, 0, i + 3)); // 3th January 2021 is a Sunday
  intlDayNames.push(intlFormatter.format(date));
}
console.log(intlDayNames); // ["Sun", "Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat"]
```

In my native language Polish situation is worse, in Intl for Sunday get e.g. "niedz." (small letter, dot) instead of Angular, 3 letters "nie".

## Where Did This Come From?

In the ECMAScript Internationalization API ([ecma402](https://tc39.es/ecma402/#datetimeformat-objects)) specification, there is a note:
> It is recommended that implementations use the locale and calendar dependent strings provided by the Common Locale Data Repository (available at https://cldr.unicode.org/), and use CLDR "abbreviated" strings for DateTimeFormat "short" strings, and CLDR "wide" strings for DateTimeFormat "long" strings.

This explains why `Intl.DateTimeFormat`  uses the "abbreviated" format for "short" strings. The ICU library, which `Intl` relies on, follows these guidelines. You can check these values in the ICU data files, such as [this one for English](https://github.com/unicode-org/icu/blob/main/icu4c/source/data/locales/en.txt#L904).
Unfortunately, there is no way to get the "Short" values from `Intl` as its "short" always returns "abbreviated".

### What I Expect

I doubt that ECMA or ICU will change their behavior regarding these formats. Therefore, I would like Angular to provide a solution that is compatible with the old behavior.

### Anything else?

### Command

### Description

I am excited about the new loader import attribute option enabled by https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/commit/24aaf1e37f49735ce97fe72fced3d53b51d6b631

Unfortunately, the karma builder can't deal with the syntax yet and produces an error like this:
```
> ng test --no-watch --browsers=ChromeHeadless

- Generating browser application bundles (phase: setup)...
âœ” Browser application bundle generation complete.

./src/app/app.component.ts - Error: Module build failed (from ./node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/src/tools/babel/webpack-loader.js):
SyntaxError: /home/runner/work/import-attribute/import-attribute/src/app/app.component.ts: Support for the experimental syntax 'importAttributes' isn't currently enabled (7:54):

   5 | import { RouterOutlet } from '@angular/router';
   6 | // @ts-expect-error TypeScript cannot provide types based on attributes yet
>  7 | import configFileContent from './app.config.ts' with { loader: 'text' };
     |                                                      ^
   8 | let AppComponent = class AppComponent {
   9 |     title = 'import-attribute';
  10 |     constructor() {

Add @babel/plugin-syntax-import-attributes (https://github.com/babel/babel/tree/main/packages/babel-plugin-syntax-import-attributes) to the 'plugins' section of your Babel config to enable parsing.

If you already added the plugin for this syntax to your config, it's possible that your config isn't being loaded.
You can re-run Babel with the BABEL_SHOW_CONFIG_FOR environment variable to show the loaded configuration:
	npx cross-env BABEL_SHOW_CONFIG_FOR=/home/runner/work/import-attribute/import-attribute/src/app/app.component.ts <your build command>
See https://babeljs.io/docs/configuration#print-effective-configs for more info.
```

I created a minimal reproduction here: https://github.com/LeonEck/import-attribute
Failing Test: https://github.com/LeonEck/import-attribute/actions/runs/10165282404/job/28112719062

Are there any plans to extend the support to the karma builder?

This commit introduces the new hybrid rendering API for Angular's Server-Side Rendering (SSR). The API aims to enhance the flexibility of SSR as discussed in https://github.com/angular/angular/discussions/56785

### Notes
- This API is currently not accessible.
- The API shape is not final.
- Additional work is required in the Angular CLI to:
  - Wire up the manifest.
  - Integrate other necessary components.

Issues.Title: Improve visibility of "Re-optimizing dependencies because lockfile has changed" state
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Description

If you server an app for the first time, and it has a substantial size of libraries, you get this experience

- Building...
- Application bundle generation complete. and browser opens
- Browser shows a blank page for a few seconds, and nothing happens
- After a few seconds, the app loads normally

This is the output:

```
Application bundle generation complete. [8.275 seconds]

Watch mode enabled. Watching for file changes...
NOTE: Raw file sizes do not reflect development server per-request transformations.
Re-optimizing dependencies because lockfile has changed
  âžœ  Local:   http://localhost:4200/
  âžœ  press h + enter to show help
```

If you don't pay very close attention, you might not see the "Re-optimizing" line. And even if you do, you don't necessarily link it to your page not loading, because it just says something about "re-optimizing", which does not sound like it's a mandatory build step. After all, there already was the output "bundle generation complete".

-> it just looks like your app is broken, and you start opening the devtools to figure out what went wrong.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I think it would be good if `ng serve` stayed in the "Building" phase while dependencies are "optimized" the first time, so that the app immediately loads when it opens in the browser.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/build): prevent build failures with remote CSS imports when Tailwind is configured
Issues.Body:
This addresses a bug where `@import url()` statements with remote CSS files (ending in .css) caused build errors when Tailwind was present. The issue arised from incorrect handling of remote URLs by the stylesheet plugin, which treated them as local files. This fix ensures proper handling of remote CSS imports.

Closes #28113

Issues.Title: Bundle order causes components to be undefined with `build-angular:application`
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

I have created a circular dependency in my project. (I know it isn't best practice to do so.)

This circular dependency causes the `DefaultDashboardComponent` to be emitted after the `dashboard-modules:DASHBOARD_MODULES` array. Which then causes the component to be undefined in this initial array.

```mermaid
graph TD
  dashboard-modules:DASHBOARD_MODULES --> DefaultDashboardComponent;
  DefaultDashboardComponent --> DashboardEndpointsService;
  DashboardEndpointsService --> dashboard-modules:findDashboardNavByKey;
  dashboard-modules:findDashboardNavByKey --> dashboard-modules:DASHBOARD_MODULES;
```

Using the older `@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser` builder didn't suffer from this problem.

### Description

Currently, AriaDescriber doesn't set descriptions if they are exactly the same as the aria-label of the element because screen readers will end up reading the same text twice in a row. A screen reader doesn't read the element's description if it's exactly the same as its accessible name.

### Actual Behavior

A screen reader reads the element's description if it's exactly the same as its accessible name, which leads the user to hear the same text twice. Only using aria-label to determine the accessible name allows avoiding this.
